text: Bottled. Small sample. The aroma has citrus, some toffee, barnyard, apple. Bit hazy, orange coloured beer with a medium sized off-white head. The taste is light-moderate bitter and has citrus, barnyard tones, herbal tones. Medium bodied beer. Very good.
2011 cloudy orange color. Large white head. Has lost a lot of its dryness over time. Huge Brett flavor. No sweetness.
Pours a medium golden amber color. Aromas of fruit, yeast and some pepper. Flavors are sour, yeasty, and a touch of sweetness at the finish.
Bottle. Poured an amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Yeast, fruity, citrus, and some some funkiness.
Great pour on this beer its a nice hay color with a very thick off white head. Extremely hoppy and sweet with a floral finish.

Aroma is clove, citrus, an earthiness and funkiness. Taste is sweet crisp maltiness with light honey and caramel. A definite sour and vinegar presence here but it finished pretty smooth. Appearance is a clear gold with a medium fluffy head that retains quite well.
Bottle, 355 ml from Za Popentt, Ljubljana. Courtesy of and shared with Kova. pours hazy orange with large white head. Malty, fruity, spicy, yeasty, bitter finish.

Either I got a bad batch or this beer is whack. HUGE carbonation level, spurted all over my desk and took 20 min to pour a decent looking beer. Yeasty flavor is about all I get other than my mouth wanting to explode from the carbonation. Some orange I guess. All 4 bottles in the pack had the same crazy carbonation. Reminds me of a high gravity homebrew bottled way too early.

Draft at the brewery. Pours hazy bright gold with a thick frothy white head. Tastes like pine and grassy hop bitterness, with some funkyness, light bready malts, and some citrus fruit, and with some lingering hop resin. Medium body and carbonation. Smells grassy, like pine, and citrus hops, biscuit and straw malts, orange peel, lemon, herbs, and some funk.
Clear amber, rocky cream head. Zesty citric aroma and bread crust. Nicely balanced, leaves a bread crust aftertaste. A mix of yeasty, simple malts and hops.
Bottle at home. Pours dark golden, nose is brett, lemon, yeasty, taste is light, sweet.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2015 Four pack at Hopey for 4.99 Good ol Hopey. I am intrigued. Really difficult pour- super carbonated. Big soapy lacey head over a nice murky amber brew. Lots of citrus - grapefruit, lemon - upfront with plenty of funk int the mid-palate and finish. Strong brett character. Belgian yeast really works here. Lots going on. Dry and crisp and green apple bitter at the end. Its well done.
03/02/2015  More funk than I remember.  Distinct barnyard aftertaste.  The older the beer gets the more prominent funk gets and the rest fades into background.  Somewhat out of balance.

Bottle. 
Opaque dark amber, huge thick white head. 
Aroma: lemon, grapefruit, grass, light brett, light soapy. 
Taste: grapefruit + lemon + peel, bitter, grass, tropical fruit, spices, balanced brett, strawberries, dry finish.
Bottle 0.355l at Oluthuone Leskinen, Oulu. Colour is deep cloudy orange with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Fruits, Belgian yeast, hops and malts. Very nice.

Bottle from mane liquor. Pours cloudy golden with a massive head.
Grapefruit notes, tastes of mellow tropical citrus hops with a hint of spice. Masses of carbonation on this one but still very tasty

Bottle, probably picked up at Whole Foods in NYC. Bright burnished orange gold colour, very high carbonation some minor gushing. Gosh actually tastes a bit like Orval. A very successful attempt at an American Belgian, the main difference I guess being a more citrusy fruity fresher less spicy hop mixture, and this is a bit cleaner, less complex and subtle. Still pretty good though!
Bottle. Deep clear amber color, white head. Aroma of light funk, pepper, spiced brown bread. Taste is light barnyard, mixed spice. Very tasty.

This was the most foam I have ever gotten from a bottle that wasnt home brew. The pour is an amber thats pretty clear. Yeast notes on the nose. Has some wine alcohol notes while staying crisp and dry. But not too dry Id say a touch of dry grape.

Grape comes on just before the brett reminds you of the Belgian element. No doubt a pale ale from the hops but Europe influence strong. A good match. 7%. 12oz. 3.6std drinks.

12oz bottle - 

I think I found my new summertime IPA. If Beverages & More continues to carry this incredible elixer, then I will continue to purchase because it has everything I love in a nice IPA. The only thing better would be if they made it more. 

The beer starts out with a clear "hiss" and gas escaping as the cap is pulled off, looking like the lid of an ancient Egyptian sarcophagus had just been lifted after 3,000 years of solitude. The beer pours out a light amber color, crystal clear. Tight bubbles form at the base, and as the beer reaches mid-glass a rather large, pillowy head forms. So much so, that when the beer glass is emptied into my glass, a 2" head has formed above the glass, sitting there like a contorted sculpture from a brewers dream. The head has incredible staying power, like a meringue of a pie made in the hands of a master chef. 

The aroma coming from the glass starts out rather tame. Light lemongrass, very floral, smells a little like grass or weeds when it gets wet. But after some time to let the head die down, and let the temp warm up a bit is when the aroma really comes thru. Strong phenols, medium spicy notes, a touch of funky-leather-jacket-rubbed-with-lemon-zest and much more farmhouse saison notes than a traditional American/WC pale ale. 

The first few sips of this hammered me with statement "this aint no sweet East Cost pale ale/IPA". Bone dry due no doubt to the brett swimming around in this beer chomping on any molecule of sugar it meets. The tartness left behind in its aggressive wake, along with the lemony-funky nature of brett, the earthy/straw-like, bitter apple peppery-ness just melds incredibly well together. Not for those that like sweet beers, its decidedly Belgian in its approach with a unique American twist on it from the masters at Green Flash. Just a clean, bright, funky treat that was made for beer geeks like me. Thank you Green Flash, for always keeping me in mind...lol.
Bottle @ Oluthuone Leskinen. Orange beer with a huge foamy white head. A fruity American-Belgian ale loaded with brettanomyces. Quite high carbonation. Very nice.

"a style i am really starting to enjoy. wish i could give every aspect of this beer an 8.5. wonderful hoppy, funky aroma. great balance. lively feel which flows right into the refreshing yet complex barnyard, citrus flavor. dry finish. after standing up to green flashs best on tap, gotta up it a tenth."

Bottled. Hazy orange color, thick creamy head. Intense, brett-infused aroma, loads of pineapple, red currants, grapes, orange blossom, leather. Dry flavor has base malts, fermented fruits, sour cranberry, strong brett wibes in the finish. Light to medium body, frothy texture. Really nice sour ale.

Large head indeed. Be careful or it will overflow upon pouring (yes, that happened to me). Yeasty fruitiness in the aroma with some sour apple in smell and taste. Sourness lingers on the tongue. Highly carbonated. A nice Belgian-style pale ale that I would drink again, but probably wont be among my mainstays.

Bottle. A huge white head covers most of the glass and table, beneath the head lies an amber colored beer. Massive carbonation. Aroma of berries, caramel, fruity yeast, brett notes. Slightly sweet palate, heavy malt notes, yeasty, nice dry bretty finish. Flowery and fruity. A nice beer, though a bit more controllable carbonation woudlnt hurt.

Not at all what I was expecting! But very pleasantly surprised!

I emagined a pretty simple little Belgian blonde, but this beer couldnt be further from that. The Brett is fantastic and really lifts this beer into the extra ordinary.

Only slight criticism is that the Brett has really got to work and this bottle Id had aging for a while was lively to say the least! But this in no way detracted from this great beer.

Reviewed from notes.
This was poured into a chalice.
The appearance was a decent hazy orange color with a two finger white head. The lacing was somewhat there and trickling but trying to stick.
The smell had a wonderful blend of fruit and yeast with notes of candy sweetness. There was a light fruit ranging close to the citrus, mango, and a light pineapple. There were some notes of a green apple sourness.
The taste took those previously mentioned flavors to encapsulate a warmingly sweet sort of fruity stickiness.
On the palate, this one sat right about a medium on the body with a tad of sessionability but honestly, this one seemed to make me want to sip it a bit.
Overall, so there is a slight sour-ness but its nothing overly done. Would I have this again? Probably.

Aroma of wheat and hops. Drank mostly out of the bottle (got a four pack). This was an incredibly foamy beer with not a lot of taste compared to other Green Flash brews (which I love). Get anything else by them before this.

I almost gave this a 5 for appearance, except the towering fluffy head would be mare at home on a tripel than on a Belgian ale. Nice yeasty aroma some floral notes, a hazy copper orange body, taste is yeast and some mellow hoppiness. Overall a great attempt at the Belgian style.

Transfer from BA review on 7-17-12 - 
 Poured from bottle into tulip glass

 Appearance  The beer pours with a nice hazy orange color with an enormous white head. The head is insanely huge with multiple pours needed to get the 12 oz bottle into a ~ 20 oz pint glass. Eventually it does fade however, to give a light amount of lacing. 

 Smell  The smell was a wonderful blend of fruit and yeast with notes of candy sweetness. The fruit was largely of citrus, mango, and a light pineapple. These aromas mingle with some other lighter aromas as well. There is also a light presence of floral hop and some notes of a green apple sourness. One wonderful smell.

 Taste  The taste starts out with a nice malty and fruity flavor. A citrus and tropical fruit sweetness mixed with a nice biscuit base. As it moves on some grapefruit citrus and a lighter floral hop come to the tongue. Accompanying these hop flavors are tastes of sour Brett yeasty flavors. As the taste advances further and goes toward the end it sours even more with other notes of more bitter hop coming to the tongue. In the end it leaves a bitter and sour flavor on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the light to medium side for the 7 % abv. As for the carbonation, it is on the slightly higher side (as would have been perceived from the super heavy head). The lighter body was slightly off putting for the hop and malt flavors, but it was good for the more sour and bitter flavors. The higher carbonation level did the same as the body and really accentuated the sour flavors of the brew. 

 Overall  A tasty sour beer with probably one of the best aromas of a beer I have ever smelt. One I would go to again given the chance.

(bottle - 12 oz) Orange pour with a lot of white head. Sweet yeast and spices in the aroma. Mild hop bitterness. Flavor has that same spicy Belgian yeast at the start with a dry hop bite coming up at the end. Way too carbonated, but pretty good.

bottle from the bottle shop in bermondsey now Belgian styles are not normaly my thing but i have to say i really liked this beer very nice fruty taste with a smooth finish not something you could drink all night because of the strength but for taste you could easily
Wonderful aroma and flavor. Floral, almost a lavender taste. Very strong on the pallate. Wonderfull beer but could be overwhelming if I had a lot more of them.

A few yrs old. Very carbonated bottle. Could not pour the entire beer in the glass at once. Several finger head. High energy bubbles. Nice lacing. Lots of Brett on the nose. Taste is dry. The beer showing signs of oxidation. A little sweetness too.

What a bretty beast... Pours a murky orange with a huge bubbly head. Brett barnyard funk dominates the nose, with some spice and a hint of fruit. Those same things are fully present in the taste, along with coriander and even a bit of a cardamom. A bit astringent. Crisp medium mouth without a lot of carbonation. Its not as refined and balanced as Orval, but nonetheless good if youre a brett head.

12oz brown bottle. Foam creeping up the neck on uncapping... a good sign? Rich golden colour, huge column of white foam, dense, thick. Huge bands of lacing in the glass. Nose has leathery bretty funk, lemony sharpness as well. Flavours of brett/funk/yeast, leathery. Mild hoppy finish, dry and crisp. Medium body with persistent carbonation. Excellent bretted pale ale, as an Orval fan this hits the mark and then some.

Pours a hazy orange with a huge frothy three finger white head diminishing gradually to a lumpy marshmallow-like cap and heavy lacing. Nose is strongly dominated by brett funk, with a little fruit and sweet malt in the background. Taste follows suit, but with more malt presence, as well as a little umami. Mouth feel is medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a gentle alcohol warming.

I see this compared to Orval, but I dont think I agree - the brett is much more pronounced than Orval, and the fruit less so. This is more like Gato Negro, with its heavy-handed brett funk, albeit with a little more West Coast character. The brett settles down somewhat as the glass progresses and the beer warms.
Poured a hazy golden colour with a head that just would not stop. Nose was musty and inviting. As close to an Orval that Ive river had. This will become a staple in my house!

Botella de 33 cl en el lúpulo, en el momento en 17-05-2014. Color ámbar con espuma beige poco persistente. Aromas y sabores ligeros, ácidos, con pequeños toques de maderas y ligeramente afrutados que se acentúan según coge temperatura. Presencia de carbónico, recuerdos a las lambic belgas con algo mas de maltas y un ligero toque amargo final bastante suave. Bastante fácil de beber. Interesante.

12oz bottle courtesy of embrouille, danke vielmals! A whole lot about this beer is a perfectly potable parody of a nouvelle vague Belgian saison: huge seafoam head, huge white pepper and pollen and springtime peach blossom nose, flowery and dry to the extreme. Orval comes to the p distracted palates mind, before it thinks better of the analogy, leaving emulation to its own devices. Taste is marked by dryness, concentrated daffodils, green apple peel and old dried citrus rind. Quite a lot to take in, almost a horror vacui of New world saison, bordering on perfume - a true West Cost feat, nevertheless.

Pours seventy five percent head twenty five percent beer. Has a urine like aroma with a flavor not far from the smell. After letting the head settle a bit this beer separates very oddly. Amber clear on bottom very foggy on top. Very upsetting overall.

12 oz bottle. golden pour, loads and loads of white frothy head, that gifts lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma, wow, lots of funkiness and thats saying something giving the fact I am at the tail end of a cold that hasnt allowed me to smell anything but mouldy ketchup for the last week. Continuing with the aroma, lemon zest, yeast, grass, very nice. Taste, nice, my first beer all week and shes a beauty, crisp dryness up front, soft mouthfeel, followed by some mild brett funk, subtle hops but very minimal, nice dry finish. Really schweet brew.
Bottle Rehills Newcastle. Pours dusty orange with a huge foaming white head. Big yeasty apple aroma, zesty lively palate, with a sharp finish, lingering and with sour notes.

12oz bottle poured into an english pint glass. A cheese like funk is noticeable right from the get-go with more subtle notes of stone fruit, resin, and earth. As the beer settles down, although the cheese is still present, a floral and citrus note make themselves apparent. The beer is a cloudy orange-gold (murky by the end of the bottle thanks to conditioning) with a light, pillowy head. The lace is runny, and doesnt stick. By the finish, the head is a dishwater film atop the beer. The tongue is hit by a medium / medium-high bitterness with a light sweetness to support it. Theres also a hint of cheesy umami in there too. Lots of light, fizzy carbonation help the medium-full bodied beer to maintain an oily texture. The finish is a dry pine, pepper, and citrus peel. The citrus peel becomes more grapefruit-like in the aftertaste, and is accompanied by a chalky quality. Some cheese flavors seem to sneak into the aftertaste as well, which is brief.
Strange brew. I get the the Belgian yeast and floral notes, but the funkiness from the Brett takes over. Very thin mouth feel. Astringent/oily. Just okay.

Bottle 660ml @Beer Hunters. Clear copper/amber color, big cloudy white head. Aroma is funky, some fruityness. Medium-bodied, very active carbonation. Flavor is also somewhat funky, citrus. "American-Belgian" yeast. Nice Orval clone.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2014 Apparently this beer is being put into retirement by GF, so I wanted to get in a bottle and rating for posterity. One of the most interesting beers theyve ever done, and in fact a fascinating beer in the entirety of American brewing. Its not Orval, but its a very interesting WC take on Orval, with a nose that is bretty as hell while conveying a lot of herbacious hop character. The flavors are delightfully spicy brett/herb union with a lasting bitterness in the finish. Theres maybe a slight hint of sweet orange peel. Bone dry. Far from my favorite beer, but there are few as distinctive as this one.

Every time I try this beer again, it grows in my estimation.  Drinking my last bottle (currently, I plan on buying all that sits around Gainesville) and its about 2 years of age.  Nose bustles with hints of lemon and mint and evergreen.  Insane carbonation and a pretty strong bitterness define the palate/taste.  Excellent summer drinker.

Another winner from Green Flash. First of all this beer is ridiculously carbonated so pour SLOWLY. Nose is belgian yeast, biscuit, malt, toast, pine. Flavor is similar with a bit of tartness, grape, darker bread, a little earthy/spicy hops. Dry. May not be characteristic of this style but it is an outstanding beer.

Pours a dark straw colour with a lot of head. Smells sweet and earthy, exciting. Decent mouthfeel, really carbonated. A bitter unbalanced taste, which mellows when when cooled to 12.5 degrees C. 

Although interesting, it is lacking a bit of balance which you can taste a room temp and I would think twice about buying again. Tasted in a glass, poured from a 12 oz bottle.

Slightly sour taste, more fizz than I expected. Overall good but not great

Aroma: Brett, leather, leaves, earthy, musty and spicy.

Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. This is a hazy golden beer that pours with a huge foamy head. It has tart earthy and spicy fruity flavours, lemon notes and barnyard sourness on the very dry finish. Excellent!

I try to get into Belgian IPAs but Im still struggling. Massive head. Huge bitterness and sweet, dry feel - like honey wine. Big taste with peat in there too. But I miss the citrus, fruit and pine notes of American IPAs. Love the West Coast IPA from these guys. Ill keep trying.

Maybe one of the last 4-packs out there. Have been a long-time fan but have not reviewed.

This one gushed on me. Poured quickly into Oxbow tulip. Enormous frothy head. Long-lasting. Took three pours to empty the bottle. Bit of lacing. Pours a slightly hazy bronze straw color.

Excellent Brett aroma. Easiest to find beer with that distinct Brett. There's some floral and fruity ester notes as well. A bit of sour cherry.

Taste is prominent Brett. Probably the oldest RV I've had based upon that. Less fruit and sweetness on tongue than nose. Some subtle hops more present than usual. Maybe a bit of oak and sour fruit.

Nice mouthfeel. Light medium with great carbonation, just shy of prickly. Very dry, as usual.

One of the best readily available Brett beers. Hopefully the shift from 12 oz to bomber won't change that. At this level of age this is closer to a heavily bretted saison than a BPA but still very good.

seriously evolving brew smells dry and sweet pours nearly amber with the largest head i have had in a while tastes like super dry cider then warms up a bit and turns into a delicious belgian sweet brew wih a a nice mini hop blast hella good brew

Not quite an Orval clone. For one thing you can pour an Orval without it practically spraying foam out of the top of your pint glass. This is the first pour Ive had in which a completely homogeneous head (not even a mm of liquid at the bottom) fills a pint glass after about the first ounce of beer. Mondo carbonation, which while it may not be a negative for some, but detracts from my rating a bit. Dry, sour, citrus sweet with excellent balance. Lingering peat and fruit. Love this beer.

Look: A lot of carbonation, too much - tends to happen with brett, Huge, rocky, white head with big bubbles at start. There was so much foam that I couldnt pour the whole bottle at once. And on the second pour the head got even more ridiculously. The head has a very slow retention, mostly stays (thick layer) - well a fucking mountain with a big valley stayed. Had to wait for a while to even start to drink. Leaves behind good amount of random lacing. Color is golden amber with some haze. Looks light, fizzy and quite alive. 


Smell: Berry, cherry, forest fruits acidity. Musty, funk. A relatively strong medicinal note with some pine, floral and herbal notes to follow. Light caramel sweetness. Everything makes a sharp, fresh, complex and interesting combo.


Taste: Funk (mostly leathery) steps up a notch and acidity tuned a bit down. Nice light caramel backbone followed with medium pine, grapefruit bitterness which stays for a while. Still some medicinal notes and some metallic ones come with a few sips. Light herbal, floral notes hidden beneath. 


Mouthfeel: Medium body, feels less because of relatively high carbonation. Dry.


Overall: Well, yes, its a Belgian ale. Some mix of bitter, light sour and gueuze. Carbonation flew too high on this one, the funk is fun and dynamic, medicinal part kinda off but overall complex and interesting one.

12 ounce to CBS glass. Amazing golden color with an almost neon glow. Opacity plus! Huge brett head even when poured slowly. There is no possible way to pour a whole bottle in a glass! Fruity aroma that wreaks of brett! Buttery, almost oily, mouth with a taste that is strong with fruit ester and yeast roll!

Sublime aroma on this beer. Its like funky Belgian tropical nirvana. Hoppier than i thought it would be. The flavors seem to effortlessly marry together. This is my kind of beer.

If there ever was an Orval clone, this is the closest Ive seen. Aroma is delightful. Aromatic floral brett tartness. I could smell this all day. Flavor is the combined brett with hops. Nice beer for sure. One Id purchase again. Got this one across the border in Wisconsin.

Almost a gusher. Eventually just had an enormous head. Was a hazy golden amber after a few minutes. Aroma is extremely yeasty and bready. Slightly spicy. Flavor follows with a nice bitter edge. Almost a hint of sourness but not off putting. Finishes dry. Nice beer.

Gusher, but I managed to contain it. Vast coarseish deep offwhite
head. Clear amber body, although at first its nearly all head.
Earthy barnyard and cow dung aroma with mealy notes.
Dry-sweet-acidic resiny tropical fruit and barnyard taste with
salty wooden notes. Mid-bodied. Sharpish, fizzy mouthfeel.
Dry-bitter resiny wooden cow dung aftertaste with citric salty
notes. A bit harsh and sharp, but has interesting aspects,
too. (0.355l bottle, from wine monopoly, Vika, Oslo.)

Une offrande explosive embouteillée le 24 août 2012. Effervescence surmenée au départ mais dès quelle se calme, les saveurs se placent. Des relents de conifères, du brett savonneux et une finale de verdure, buvabilité toxique.

12oz bottle. Clear light amber with a huge lasting straw-coloured head. Lovely aroma - fruity and floral, fairly strong alcohol - simple, quite bitter too. Taste follows but with a real funky "Orval" bite to it - average body, very airy, astringent, spicy, dry, quick-finishing with a slightly tart fruit aftertaste ... surprised how much I like it.
Bottle in Iowa. Way to much funk, made ir awful for me. Brett or something overwhelmed me

Massive carbonation requiring a slow pour and still resulting in a sizable head. Aroma musty hay & funk from the Brett & citrus from the hops. Taste is funk, lemon zest, coriander, with some good body from the malt & a light sourness in the finish. Not too bad.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2014 12 oz bottle from Tipsys into my Funkwerks tulip glass. Orange and cloudy with a big, lasting white head. Aroma is tart, funky, fruity, bretty and lightly sour, quite enticing. Similar flavor with an earthy bitterness and a dry feel. Refreshing and tasty as fuck.  Update:  Other bottles of this havent been quite 4.0, but close.  Still, top notch and fantastic in some bottles/batches.
Sweet lemon aroma, huge bone white foam at first pour this beer has the Belgian yeast, malty body and green hop aftertaste. Easier drinker, lighter than expected.

12 oz bottle poured into a trappist glass. Huge head formed from massive carbonation, took 4 pours to get it all out of the bottle. Decent aroma, nothing too funky going on here. Taste is crisp and thin. Good beer, will enjoy again.

Green flash pale ales have this really recognizable house aroma. I like this more than their friendship brew. It has a Belgian flavor but not as easily found as I am used to. Pretty resiny and dank hops. There was a relentless cloud of head when I poured. Ok combination of the green flash taste with Belgian style. Not fantastic

Not my favorite style, but decided to give a single a try from Archer Liquors in Chicago. Massive head is probably an understatement. Taste is pretty weird to me, hops, orange peel and a medicinal / sour taste. Hey, I can say I tried it.

Supposedly an Orval clone, but I find the aftertaste more appealing than that of Orval. Pours with tremendous head settling into a nice copper color. The aroma and taste are quite similar to a great Brittany brut cider.

January 18th, 2012 - Rayon Vert is Green Flashs alternate reality beer, developed in a world where Green Flash began in Belgium, not San Diego. This alternate history opens up Green Flashs brewing to the great outdoors and invites in Brettanomyces - a flavor Americans, I think, I still getting accustomed too. Fortunately for Brett amateurs, the barnyard funk only appears in the taste. Funky freshness and cobwebs lurk in the depths of the flavor, though brightened by the elegant taste of rosewater and a heavy hit of perfume. Be prepared to get more than a few sips of waxy flower petals on the tongue, but its a worthwhile experience.

It continues the fruity aspects of the aroma but this is where it starts to feel more like an IPA than a Belgian ale. Still, this is an American take on the style, not a carbon copy, so thats not an issue. More of that brett coming through as as the slightly sour undercurrent that underpins everything. Mouthfeel is quite soft and it makes for easy drinking. Overall this is a really good effort from Green Flash.

My Bottom Line:
Brettanomyces, flowers and eau de cologne allusions whirl about in this dry, very drinkable Wild Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sizeable head of foam clings to the misty amber shine (looks great without the yeast pour).
-Carbonation is appropriately high yet soft on the palate (not biting).
-The nose is amazingly Orval-like.
-The flavor profile is of a medium intensity.
-This is not the most complex offering, but it sure is well-made and greatly satisfying.

Green Flash Rayon Vert has an extremely thick, whipped cream-type off-white head (actually it exploded everywhere when I popped the cap) and a brilliant, reddish-orange appearance, with some streaming bubbles and about the thickest lacing imaginable present on the glass. The aroma is fruit forward, with orange peel, orange juice, sugar, and possibly even Orange Julius in the smell. Taste is of the highest order- fruit, Mandarin orange, marmalade, orange peel, orange rind, white bread, white bread crust, sugar, yeast, a mild hop bitterness, and white pepper. Mouthfeel is light to medium and slick, and Green Flash Rayon Vert (Green Flash, in English) finishes mostly dry, smooth, mellow, and supremely drinkable. Overall, this is world class to the hilt. Incredible!
Appearance is large white head with clear amber. Aroma is a little sweet. Taste is a little malty with some sweet hops. Overall an interesting mix that falls short.

Hazy golden with big soapy head and good lacing.  Floral smell with earthy hops and some brett character.  Briny taste of brett yeast and hops come through with the floral taste.  A slight metallic taste. Moderate mouthfeel with high carbonation.  Really good.  Would definitely try again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours hazy yellow orange. Aroma is strong hops with some citrus and horse blanket.  Taste is strong with the Brett yeast with some brininess.  Hoppy taste with only a little bitterness at end. A little soapy.  Not great.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, pours clear golden orange with a massive, merengue-like white head. Spicy Belgian yeast on the nose; white pepper, floral hops, a hint of lemon peel. More citrus in the body, with puckering astringency that works well with the vigorous carbonation. If this were a bit softer, I would go through it like gangbusters.

Bottle - Pours hazy golden with a ridiculous foamy white head. Nose is dry and spicy, with funky plastic brett, leather and perfumed soap. Way too dry, astringent, and plasticy for my tastes. Taste is the same, with a bit of white pepper and fruitiness on the finish. Huge fluffy carbonation in the mouth, though its a bit biting. Not my favorite.

Hazy orange with a large, rocky, white head. Aroma is bright fruit, spice, yeast, sweet, light citrus. Medium bodied. Flavor is  bright, fruity, citrus masterpiece. Spice from yeast, and lightly sweet malts, too. Very enjoyable, very complex. Body is fairly full with decent carbonation. I think a little more carbonation would really add to the complexity of this but who the hell am I to judge? Dryish finish. Great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 Hazy pale orange with out-of-control frothy head.  Its alive!  Lovely nose of dried tropical fruit, mango, grapefruit, peach, pine hopping, Belgian yeast, spice, and bretty leather.  Flavor is a dry, tropical fruit cocktail with perfectly-matched, thick, layered bitterness, grapefruit, pine and brett leather.  Nicely dry and hoppy on the finish with some dried mango.  Absolutely world-class in my opinion.  Has the complexity and drinkability that I love.  Re-rate: can be large variability from batch to batch.  Brett can be tricky.  Reality rate -0.2

Pours a hazy golden color with a huge head that fades very slowly with lots of lacing. Aroma of yeast, fruity, with some banana, spice. Taste of banana, vanilla spice with a mild fruity sweetness and spice. has sort of a tart bitterness and an unexpected dry finish. Medium body, smooth and creamy. No hint of the 7% ABV. This beer is quite complex with a lot going on. Very enjoyable beer, better than I expected. worth checking out.

25-DEC-2012, bottle @Morten.
Huge off-white, fluffy head with laces on hazy orange body.
Nice yeasty aroma with a little funk and malty fruit.
Taste the same with even more brett and gun powder. Sweet, malty, fruity tartness. Dry, creamy. Delicious.

Bottle shared by Drew. Thanks! Pours a pale gold with a sticky white head. Nose is citrus and fruit forward. Huge head kind of obfuscates. Some sweetness in the nose. On tasting, pilsner malt and citrus. Sweet and fruity, not as dry as anticipated. Some white pepper and vanilla on the palate as well. Okay but not as great as advertised...

Huge surprise with this beer. A last minute grab from the store. Pours a beautiful golden with a touch of bottle haze. Gorgeous carbonation, with lingering lace. Aroma is earthy and spicy, with classic brett character. Nice balance of aroma hops, really compliment the brett. Drinks easily, with a wonderful dry finish. Very complex flavor profile, lemon, and horse saddle, hops, and that wonderful underlying Belgian yeast. Truly an outstanding beer. Highly recommended.

A solid beer and glad we can finally get it. This beer is a hazy golden color with a 4 finger head even when poured gently. So much aroma to this beer with huge lemon zest and other melons with a hint of some Belgium yeast maybe. Love the "funk" this beer has. The taste hits you with some bite on the front, not hoppiness but rather as if it were lemon zest. This mellows out nice with some really nice tang and then finishes nice and dry. This was a little different as I wasnt sure what to expect. Can be addicting in a weird way.

Brilliant golden in colour, pours with a large head. Smells green fruits, melon, pine and brett funk. Tastes like big bretty, with some sweetness, malts, green fruits/melons hints, coriander maybe..couldnt quite identify it. Pretty nice.

pours a cloudy orange, very nice white foamy head that sticks around, Nice citrus, tangerine aroma with some spicyiness. Light astringence with some bitterness. Also some chalk. Finish is dry and tangy. Enjoyable.

This was my second bottle of this beer. As a matter of fact, it will be the first I have been able to sample because the first made it across the Pacific to New Zealand, sat briefly in my possession and then the bottom broke off, spreading in a sour, bubbly puddle across my garage. I am thankful it didnt happen on my livingroom carpet. I am also thankful it didnt happen within cooee of MrsJimthechap or this rating would never have occurred.
Rayon Vert is a murky orange brew with voluminous white head that took up an easy 60% of the glass. Left to settle it gave good head and some lace. Aromas of freshly squeezed orange juice, some grapefruit and a definite nod to its Belgian origin. I have read that the brewer intended this beer to be as close to its origin without reference to Saccharomyces and I am of the mind that if beer had never had Louis Pasteur and the chaps from Carlsberg et al, Green Flash would still be sought after. It wasnt pungently basement or needlessly sour. It still had the approach-ability of a new world spontaneously fermented ale (if a little lively, considering my first bottle sadly missed).
Tasting unveiled that tartness, lemon, orange, citron and then peel. It had a nod to unripe apricot as its malt component but sour tartness was the boss of this choir. Lipsmacking and an  interesting sideshow to other beers from this stable, but I would assert that we were gifted advances in yeast culture an inoculation and should make the best of this. I would leave Belgian Ale to the Belgians. Sorry*.

*Not sorry at all, love your work Green Flash and love Belgian ale. You just dropped a bollock.

Orange color with good sized white head. Earthy hoppy smell with citrus, pine, soap. Highly carbonated with a crisp hop bite and a soapy tinge to the taste as well. Aftertaste is a little bit of the citrus hops and earthy Brett but I don't care for the odd soap like vibe going on. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Botella. Color daurat amb escuma blanquinosa excessiva. Aroma de pell de taronja, terra. El gust és lleugerament picant i àcid. Cos mitjà, carbonatació animada i escumosa sensació a la boca. Massa carbonatació. No obstant això, es saborosa i ben equilibrada.

Cloudy golden with a big, but disappearing white head. Big brettanomyces aroma with grapefruit and leather and a little more grass and herbs than Orval. Grassy and funky flavour with fruity notes, and a floral hint. Rather dry with a good bitterness. A good clone, but basically a simpler and more expensive Orval.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 12oz unique bottle.  Kind of a gusher, which is sort of acceptable for the style.  Continuously evolving indeed.  Dry mellow tropical hop aroma, big brett and farmhouse funk, bubblegum..really nice.  Top notch stuff really, boldly dry.  More in line with a funked out Saison than a BPA..whatever...sounds good to me.  Aggressive and in your face, this is certainly a really great beer.  Really Orval like.  Quite nice.
Additional notes- this is really overcarbonated.  The fluffy palate is nice at first, but is really over the top, making it a challenge to really sit down and drink this beer.

Bottle. A billowing off white head tops a very pretty deep brass orange colored brew. There is a nice leathery nose with some typical brett funk. It is not fishy, but reminds me of the smell of fresh oysters, like the ocean.There is also some  nice citrus behind the sea smells. This taste like a funky light leathery orange rind. There is some note of dandelions in the aftertaste. Highly carbonate,d but otherwise, very smooth. Another solid winner from Green Flash.

23.11.12. Bottle. Large, fluffy, quite airy foam (porous), off-white. Clear orange beer. Aroma is lemon, sugar, fresh and piney. Reminds me of some household cleaning agent. Flavor is bitter, dishwashing liquid, yeasty. High carbonation (too much for me). Aftertaste is a dry, one-dimensional bitterness; short.What the label calls a "delightful effervescence" is far from the truth in my case. Much, much too bubbly. The overall aroma of soap or whatever really diminishes the score in my case. Strange beer.

Bottle, cheers to thepeter for the pour! The appearance is slightly hazy gold with a medium white head. The nose is funky wild brett, some marshamllow, apricot, soft orchard fruits and mild citrus. The taste is pleasing citrus hoppiness, spruce. Glorious pillowy brett finish. Light body, active carbonation. Overall, a really nice beer.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours with a huge head of foam. So much so that it takes several minutes to completely drain the bottle. Body is a hazy dark orange with amazing head retention and lacing.

Aroma is almost all Brett. I can detect some lemon coming through but barely underneath the barnyard funk.

The taste is largely the same: Brett. Now I do love this flavor in the correct style or if properly balanced but that is not the case here. Im not sure of the age of this beer but the Brett has really taken over leaving just a faint hint of lemon and bread underneath and nearly no bitterness. Mouthfeel is soft with a slightly sticky finish.

Overall, I was expecting a lot more complexity from this beer. It almost reminds me of a poorly made Geuze. Might have to revisit this sometime.

Bottle.  Nose is sweet with fruity hops and nice fresh yeast.  Pours hazy orange with a lacing and slightly leggy beige head, maintains its pillows but doesnt degrade gracefully.  Crisp sharp feel, strong bitterness with plenty of yeast (the main character), Bretty strongly with BPA-type hops, and on the whole very dry with a touch of scratchiness.  Mild alcohol.  Among the commercial beers Ive tried, this is about as close to Orval as has been managed on American soil.
Bottle thanks to the Peter. Funky brett aroma. Pretty good attempt. Bit unbalanced. Good stab at a pretty belgian

Bottle thanks to thepeter. Slow gusher. It pours cloudy golden yellow with a massive off-white head. The nose is orange peel, earth, tartness, bread, panettone, apple and pear. The taste is spice, earth, candied peel, zesty orange, alcohol warmth, hay, bread and decent bitterness. Medium body, lively carbonation and foamy mouth-feel. Too much carbonation. Nevertheless a flavoursome and well balanced beer.

Bottle 12 fl. oz. Pours cloudy goldenamber in color with a massive, creamy off-white head. Leather, barnyard, some lemon and floral notes in aroma. Really nice. Sweet fruity, some banana and bitter grassy hops in taste. Well balanced, tasty brew thats really refreshing. Dry, bitter and feels even sligthly sour in aftertaste, with some barnyard notes beeing as well in there.
This beer is quite sour for just an ordinary Belgian pale. Not really anything much in the aroma bir certainly an interesting flavor.

pour is a dark copper, mostly transparent, with an off white tight head.  Nose is light leather, faint dust, strong lemon and citrus with a lingering leather in back.  Taste is very good, dusty and leathery, bright citrus and lemon, rather bitter and semi dry in the finish. Carbonation is decent, would prefer high carb but not bad. Very balanced and tasty, solid depth.
crazy aroma. delicious taste. bought this in cardiff by the sea and at 8.99 /4-pack i was very happy

12 ounce bottle.  This is one of those beers that foam-explodes when you pour it into a glass, so proceed with caution.  Once you get past all that foam, it has a nice and fresh veggie-oriented aroma and flavor that I really enjoyed.  Appearance is an opaque orange, heavy lacing and heavy, durable doses of foam.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and satisfying. Overall its a pleasant, grassy, sudsy hopped and vegetable-tinted, maybe even bubble-gum oriented and ipa-leaning BPA. Its well executed and worthy of a spot on your mix-six line up, given its the middle-of-the-road price.

Pours out a bright hazy golden orange with a bright sparkly white head. Gorgeous lacing rings form. The nose is crisp and intense with light citrus hops, a zesty and estery yeast aroma with big barnyard brett and funk. Beautiful and refreshing flavour...delightful fruits and light malts. Then a delightful crisp and dry finish. Quite astringent but not off-putting...just a nice well balanced brew.

Pours to a hazy, orange with a clear white head and great lacing. The aroma is strong on the front end. One smells that delicious Belgian yeastiness and herbs. The taste is a bit sour and coats the sides of the tongue, then yields to a nice malty back end. Very nice brew.

Appearance was clear orangish gold with creamy lasting huge mosterious white head(half glass), lacing throughout. Aromas are sweet pale,crystal, caramel malts with estery floral yeasts of bubblegum, bananas, Hefe-like and spicey herbal piney hops. Taste beligian profile yeasts domaniate the profile with spicey, piney, touch of sourness,funky bretts, lemon hops and slight pale base, no alcohol present. Palate was creamy soft Co2 with light-mediom body, then the lasting piney yeasty finish. It was clear, stirred up the yeasts with last pour, its cloudy. Funky tasting also...

Small bottle at Hops in New West. Small whitish head. A pale orange color, sweet and fruity on the nose. Bittersweet and fruity on the tongue. Finish is long, with lingering aftertaste. Afterthoughts: bittersweet, fruity, complex flavours at work here. Very nicely done.

From a bottle, pours into a frosted glass with a fluffy foam head that goes straight to the top. That happens again when I pour again. Id think it was a fluke but another review mentioned it. No harm, though. Great, earthy, hoppy aroma, with some yeast. Flavor is similar - rich, complex, earthy hops but smooth.

Fruity aroma has a yeasty overtone and a malty underpinning. Pours a pretty clear amber with a very thick and fluffy eggshell head. Sharp flavor is fruity and a little sour, with malty and yeasty undertones and a hint of woody hops. Smooth, firm texture has a subtle but persistent tingle and leaves a fruity, slightly hoppy finish. Overall, decent.

The initial pour produced total foam from the bottom of the glass and up over the top. As the foam opened up, it settled into a clear medium yellow body below. 
The aroma is quite interesting and quite  persistent. The tall head did not hold it back as many big heads will do.  Sweet and complex; almost like the smell of new soft vinyl but a bit leathery. Some bubblegum.
The flavor is lightly herbal with a nice dry finish.
Ill have another!

Bottle at home. Pours a cloudy dark orange colour with a huge frothy light beige head. Very fruity aromas of apricot, but also sweet and bitter berries from the woods. Theres also some heather and oak, and its like standing in the middle of the forest. Wonderful and lightly spiced. The flavour hits me with lots of pine, oak and leather. If the aroma smells of forest, the flavour is like licking the forest trail. The mouthfeel is pretty flat and slick, and has a medium bitterness. A really one of a kind beer which is powerful in the nose as in the mouth. I think Ive never recalled that many memories from the cabin in the mountain forest in a beer before!

Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Valkendorfsgate, Bergen. Pours a dark and slightly hazy orange body with a large creamy off-white head. Aroma is Belgian ale yeast, candy fizz, red berries, pineapple, some sour bretty hints and red apples far in the back. Nice and quite complex. Taste is brown sugar, pine, wet grass, alcohol, dry Belgian yeast tones and hints of oranges. Very nice. A bit too fizzy, even for a Belgian but all in all a nice, hopped-up version from the U.S.

12 oz bottle to flute
Apricot, Brett, orange, and hay on the nose. Slightly cloudy amber with a thick bubbly head. Taste is sweet with bitterness throughout. Light body with a  thin texture.

12oz bottle from a four pack that was $9 I believe. Ive been avoiding Green Flash beers due to the lack of bottle dating, change to four-packs, and price hikes but this one sounded very interesting so I broke my boycott. Bright orange at first and then very hazy as the yeast makes its way into the glass. Little bit of head and a little lace on the glass. The smell is fruit, slight hops and a very subtle hint of the brettanomyces yeast, not bad. The flavor is a little fruity and then a hint of bitterness that reminds me of aspirin without being offensively medicinal. Sort of dry on the tongue too. Overall? good enough that after buying a single I went back for a couple more four-packs.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-03-2012 21:32:12

Bottle poured with a deep golden color and a huge fluffy two finger head that could have easily got out of control. Aroma has brett, lemon zest, peppery hops, basement funk, Belgian yeast, and pear. Mouth feel is light and there is plenty of frothy carbonation. Flavor has brett, aged grassy hops, light citrus, and there is some wet herbs in there. The aroma seems to have a lot more layers than the flavor brings out. It is a real nice drinking beer but i wish the brett in the flavor was not so far out in front of everything else.

From a 355ml bottle on 15/11/2012. Pours a fairly clear light golden with a huge billowy head. Has a strong sharp, citrusy, yeasty aroma. Flavour wise you get lots of lemon, a touch of apple, and a tart, tangy, rather salty, dry finish which dominates the modest sweetness up front. This has some saison like character to it, but its more in your face. The carbonation is too high in my view. Gotta say Im quite disappointed with this. The Green Flash gear Ive tried to date has ranged from excellent to exceptional, but this is just passable. Its not lacking in flavour or character - its just that whats there is not particularly interesting, inspiring or enjoyable.

Pours a cloudy dull golden with lots of nice billowy white head. Lots of interesting woody aromas...chardonnay/saison impressions. Flavours are tart and bitter citrus....and just enough sweetness to round it out. Excellent.
Sweet Belgian yeast with a bitter finish. Very flavourful beer from Green Flash.

Huuuuge disappointment, so Im going off on a rant here.  Refrigerated for several days.  A very careful pour produced 70% foam that was as thick as meringue and had to be spooned away. The aroma is leathery (but not good leather....think "genuine imitation leather" made in China) and it has a gross, medicinal plasticity.  Unfortunately, the medicinal plastic note translated to the aftertaste.  Yep, thats what I want... a band aid on my tongue...not.  Sure, this is a BPA with Brett.  As a card carrying beer geek, Im supposed to like this.  However, Id prefer to nurse a bottle of  Old English 800 cut with orange juice.  Comparisons to Orval are a certified joke.  The two couldnt be further apart.  This beer is a shameful atrocity and it has earned my lowest rating thus far.

Slightly cloudy golden pour, fluffy white head. Funky aroma, medicinal/band aid which overpowered everything.  I was worried Id got a dud bottle; fortunately didnt taste like band aids. Dry, spicy peppery flavour with obvious yeast influence on the taste. Not at all bad..but the aroma worried me. Ill pick up another bottle and hopefully need to edit this review

12 oz. bottle purchased @ Julios Liquors for $3.54 after Wild Six discount. English pint shows me a clear gold color with large amounts of head due to over-carbonation. Aromas of Belgian yeast and a light farmhouse funk. Taste is yeast, grapefruit pith, light pale malt and Brett shows up through out the sip. Lightly funky. Lighter side of medium in body. Texture is dry with the Brett building up as you drink.

This is a very interesting beer. It has a nice fruity aroma, whit some apricot nose. The taste is the most interesting part, I almost wanna say that feels like a marriage between a good Belgian ale and a dry Sauvignon Blanc. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2012 Poured 2 oz. into my 12 ounce tulip and head overflowed. Kind of ridiculous. Took 15 min just to get the whole bottle intoy glass. Nice yeasty hop aroma with fruity floral notes. Clear golden orange once the fluff disappears off the top. A lot of funk on the flavor in a good way. I was expecting something very hop forward but this was closer to an effervescent farmhouse belgian. Very nice fruit, spice and yeast flavor with just a but of nice hop bite. A refreshing and well done brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A bonus from Daknole. Cloudy yellow pour with a thickwhite frothy head. Aroma had a slight funk to it with a hint of yeast and spice. Taste was spicy, dry, yeast. A touch of funk. Nice lacing.

Bottle at home, from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass. Pours clear deep orange, 2-finger thick cream coloured head, exceptional lacing. Nose is intense grassy hops, lots of soap, tons of yeast esters buzzing around in here... Lots of grass and spice, was kinda hoping for more hops here... Flavours of big yeast, lemongrass, hay, sherbet lemons, earth, just the lightest touch of funk, spicy lemon finish, with a hint of white pepper. Solid brew.

An extra from Dak -- many thanks! First big "hiss" Ive heard from popping a bottles lid in a while. Its body is orangeage wirg a fluffy, big-assed white head. Smells remarkably of a Saison, Belgian yeast, hay, seaweed and European hops. Apparently theres Brett in this -- nice! Tastes of Belgian yeast, maybe some coriander, lime and funk by swallow. Decent stuff.
Lively to say the least, an explosion as it was poured. Familiar taste and smell, but cant pinpoint. Definitely unique
From a 12 oz bottle at a tasting. Pours a cloudy yellow with s large bubble head. Orange zest and cardamon in the nose. Brett flavors. Nice.

Large exhaltation of air upon opening and a nice large 1 1/2 inch plus head of varying sized bubbles formed in the glass with tons of carbonation.  Slightly funky aroma with some mint, spices, herbal aromas, pineapple and some cat urine.  Very complex aroma with lots to behold.  Color is a medium golden brown.  Very lively in the mouth with tons of effervescence.  More herbal and spicy flavors with some dandelion leaves and dry bitterness.  Light malt profile.  This brew really remidsme of a Fantome brew.  Very reminiscence of a saison.  Finishes bitter and dry with more herbs and spices.  A decent and unexpected brew.

#1200 12oz bottle. The aroma is lovely barnyard and horseblanket brett along with black pepper, faint citrus fruit, pomme fruit and floral notes. Huge white head sits atop the copper colored and effervescent beer. Taste is black pepper, powerful brett, lightly toasted malt and herbal. Active carbonation tickles the mouth. Well attenuated. Dry finish. Lingering white pepper and barnyard flavors. This has quickly become one of my go to beers.

This is the best beer Ive had from Green Flash.  It pours with a lemon meringue presentation.  There is a lot of carbonation  and piles and piles and piles of bubbly head that just doesnt go away.  The excessive head is the closest thing there is to a down side, here.  The aroma s hoppy, with big, warm, buttered bread notes and some citrus, and the flavor is just a knock-out.  Bananas and mildly grassy hops, rich but mild malt and a little kick in the finish.  I will buy this again, and not in singles.

Melbourne, Australia - imported bottle by Phoenix Beers. This is a fantastic beer. It might be a little over-carbonated as even when I am gentle the bottle gushes a little. Big white rocky head, light golden hazy yellow colour. Funky brett aroma, but combined with some good ol Green Flash hopping rates, grass and barn-yard funk aroma. Light bodied mouthfeel, but wow, what a flavour, theyve cut through the funk with some hoppy bitterness, clean hop profile. I just love this beer.

Bottle.  Huge head on this mostly clear gold beer. Some lace.  Aroma is very full, nice dusty grass, and intensely Brett.  Flavor is Brett, biscuits, and very dry and finishes strongly pithy bitter.  Its very soft and with lively carbonation.  Fantastic beer.

GF have had a fair crack here. Bretty, dry minerals, pepper, some saison-like spice; a lot happening. Orval-like given the pepper and minerals. Not sure if I was won by the style but the execution is excellent.

(Bottle, 0.65 l, at Porvoon Kekri, 20121026) The beer poured  golden and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had fruitiness, citricness, tartness and spiciness. Palate was medium bodied with quite high carbination. Flavours were fruitiness, wild yeast, grapefruit, sweetness, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was yeast, hoppy and bitter. Nice hoppy beer with fitting Belgian style yeastiness.
bomber. Chunky, pillow white head. Nose of funky hops & farm smells. Bubbly, slightly tart mouthfeel. Easy funk.

pours cloudy orange with a massive wtf foamy head, very sticky lacing, large clusters of fast CO2 streams. Sour tangy apple and mild barnyard on the nose. Very creamy mouthfeel up front, balanced 7/10-sweetness, tastes of barnyard, ginger, cloves, nutmeg, bitter tangerine peel, and a long nutmeg exhale. Med-high complexity, med-high depth, great transitions, excellent carry, great drinkability. Fab Belgian-Pale Ale hybrid.

Bottle. Moderate aromas all around, with grain for the malt, herbs and lemon grass for the hops, barnyard for the yeast, with hints of sour apple, ginger and clove. Head is huge, frothy/fizzy, white with excellent crusty lacing and is fully lasting. Color is hazy, light amber/orange. Flavor starts moderately acidic, then finishes moderately acidic and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is on the lighter side of medium, between dry and watery in texture and has a fizzy carbonation. Well rounded aromas up front head up this Belgian Ale, while a nice spiciness backs it up.

12oz bottle. Hazy amber orange with a huge, foamy off white head. Aroma is musty barnyard, toast and spice. Flavor is lightly tart, rich malt and lightly bitter hops. Medium body with active carbonation. Fresh, this one is excellent but with a little age the brett comes out and makes it better. Outstanding beer, just like Orval but way cheaper.

Aroma is sweet and belgian. Fruity as well. Appearance is cloud bronze with a big lasting white head. The taste starts belgian yeast flavored with a good amount of hops at the finish. I am getting a very good floral taste as the yeast and hop flavors mix. Very pleasing considering I belgians aren't my fave. The palate us decent and not too overpowering as some belgians are.    Overall, a great take on mixing the two styles to make them better together, in mu eyes.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Poured a dark golden color with huge frothy head.  Nice blend of belgium yeast and citrus hop in the aroma.  Medium light bitterness.  Citrus hop taste with a bit of pine and belgium flare, coriander, clove  Medium body.  Ave carbonation. Would get again.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle.  

Bottle erupted foam upon opening.  Poured into glass as almost all foam.  Once settled, it left  hazy, golden amber liquid with huge billows of pale tan foam for a head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of wet hay, biscuit malt, white pepper, Brett funk, citrus and green apple. 

Taste of grapefruit zest, orange, pepper, Brett, green apple and biscuit malt.  A little grapefruit tartness, but not what you would call a "sour beer" and not very bitter, despite all the citrus.

Medium/light body and medium/high carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
awesome brett aroma with lemon and light hops. nicely balanced flavor, slightly horsey with fuzzy hops and crisp malt. medium body, yeast-hop finish.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2012 Bottle from mane liquor. Nose has lots of sweet fruits with sour notes too. Pours a golden hazy body with a nice white head with ok lacing. Very spritzy and highly carbonated. Taste of citrus fruits, pine, banana combining well with mild malts. Not overly hoppy just fruity and sourish. Very easy to drink. Not overly bitter

35,5cl Bottle. Trade with Fonefan. Pours deep cloudy orange with a large fluffy head. Nose is brett, fruit and hops. Quite intense and "Orval-ish". Fresh fruity hoppy bitter flavor with a good bretty bite and dryness. Delicious.

Pours hazy orangish color with white head. Bretty and yeasty aromas with floral hops. Slightly sweet fruity flavor with bready yeast, grassy hops and brett. Medium body with lovely carbonation and a dry finish. Good stuff.

This unique beer has somewhat of a hazy light orange/gold color and an off-white head.  It definitely looks Belgian in style.  The aroma is very soapy and barnyard-like, and just a little of manure, a little wet grass, and hint of chicken poop.  It, honestly, reminds me of the rodeo (a green one).  That said, its aroma is very strong, but oddly enough unoffensive (considering).

A little sweetness contributes in the flavor; otherwise, those green barnyard characteristics carry through in the mouth. A: Pours a...HOLY BAJEEZUS LOOK AT THE HEAD ON THIS THING! For the briefest of split seconds, I thought it was infected, then I realized nope, this is just a brett beer. Anyhoo, the beer pours a milky golden yellow color with vibrant carbonation trails rising to the top. Like I said before, the head on this is truly epic, taking up 3/4ths of the entire glass after non-aggressively pouring the beer for a couple seconds. The heads color is eggshell. At first, the head starts off with big bubbles and a soapy texture, but as the yeast near the bottom is mixed in, the head becomes denser in its construction. Massive clumps of lacing are left on the glass as the head retains itself in infuriating fashion. Aesthetically jaw-dropping.

S: The scent is downright bi-modal; at first I get bubblegum, cream soda, peppermint, candied sugar, and licorice. Once the beer has been left to sit a while, notes of grass, band-aids, and yes, horse blanket-y funk. Extremely interesting to say the least.

T: Initially has a slightly sour, phenolic edge to it. This ultimately gives way to a grassy, funky finish, with traces of bubblegum and citrus abounding. Also features a general graininess throughout resembling a good pilsener. After lovingly waxing on how beautiful this looked and how great it smelled, Im disappointed I dont have more to say on this one. Its just a solid, well made BPA with a (welcome) funky twist, nothing that blows the mind, but one that refreshes nicely on a warm late spring day. For what its worth, this is the second Green Flash beer that smelled much better than it tasted.

M: Quite astringent...after several successive sips, though, this astringency calms down to become a general dryness. It still manages to be refreshing despite its heavier texture, which is damn hard to pull off. Well carbonated without being overly intense.

O: It is what it is, and thats a solid no-frills pale ale with a nice brett infusion. The funk may require a little getting used to, but this is a great place to start for drinkers unfamiliar with brett beers.

12 oz bottle. Pours hazy amber (swirled) w/ large and bubbly white head. Aroma is, well, great. Flavor is extremely, extremely dry, spicy yeastiness. It has to be said: GF is one damn fine brewery-- not just one that can make a bunch of amazing hoppy beers.

A lasting sheet of small white bubbles stays atop the veiled gold. Resinous and wild flowery Brettanomyces Bruxellensis takes a lot of room in this gently horsey, highly estery (yellow and orange fruits) ale which, when relatively cold, feels much lighter than 7%, but when it warms up, has quite an alcohol kick stepping in, together with higher alcohol vapors. Despite the beer being a few months old, hops are still quite evident, but they are interestingly matching the Brett flavours with furthermore flowery and oily resin nuances. In mouth, the palate is well dried out, throwing spicy yeast notes all around. The bready malts seem content with their support role and are dominated by the vigorous effervescence, evolving into a small-bubbled foaminess once the beer has settled for a few minutes. There are a few things I would prefer otherwise, but my general impression is very positive here despite having always prefered Green Flash for their hoppy stuff than belgian attempts. Less alcohol and lesser ester and higher alcohols would make it Orvalesque and gorgeous to me, but as it is, it remains pretty good stuff and something I would drink a six-pack of during a party with pleasure.

Pours into a towering, loose, fluffy, off-white head that takes its time receding into a hazy amber-orange body. The nose is a blend of dry Brettiness and light, fruity yeast notes (pear and apple). Also present is a distinct vinyl note that is a surprisingly pleasant addition to the medley. Once the head dissipates, however, the vinyl note nearly disappears and the aroma becomes more integrated with a touch of spice added to the mix. The palate is light to medium-bodied with soft, fine carbonation and a drying, somewhat tart and moderately funky/sour (good funk) finish. The flavor is less fruity than the nose, with the Brett dominating the flavor profile: horse blanket funk and a mild white pepper note take front stage over a pale malt back that just hints at the apple and pear notes found in the aroma. Quite drying and funky with additional phantom notes of leather and peach pit dancing in and out of focus. This is the kind of beer that could simultaneously scare craft beer newbies away from "Belgian-Style" Pale Ales and make Brett fans hear "Ode to Joy" in their heads. I lie somewhere between those two groups. I enjoy the nuances that it possesses but I would have preferred it have dialed-in closer to where the nose is at this point. This is definitely an interesting beer, and if Brett is your thing, this is a good candidate to cellar and crack one every 3-6 months to see how it evolves.

At just on cool, a small bottle - dont want to over commit. With only half in the chalice it raised an enviable white clowd of foam that adheres like glue to the walls of the glass. Sits, just shy of bright and dazzling in the lights; a deep, orange amber with very sparse and very fine carbonation. A top up with the rest of the beer it disperses a fine haze of yeast that turns it pastel in tone. Got a nice tweak of the funked-up, hessian-sack, Brett notes coming through on the nose. A good whiff of salted white cheese, drift-wood, mouse hair, white bread dough too with inklings of ripe, soft, tropical fruits to round it off nicely; very pleasing and subtle. Dry, tart, woody and all consumed Brettanomyces charged palate. Hops in equal synch. I half expected it to be rife with resinous US hops but this is so pleasingly balanced. Body is firm, not light, not heavy, with the carbonation offering to elevate it well and pierce every seem, every nook, every cranny of the mouth. Flavour reminiscent of hessian-sack, driftwood and vine-clippings, tart strawberries and peachy fruit esters, vanilla and musk candy in late. Puckering, hairy, undeniably dry swallow sees it tail off quickly with only a little yeasty funk to reminisce on. A pleasant surprise for me. An original ale, well made, beautifully crafted. Lovely! Grassy fruity yeast esters. Citrus peel  hop bitterness. Slight peaty smokiness. Brett sour. Complex playground of flavors. Much better than anticipated.

Bottle from Ricks in Alexandria. Served in a Green Flash Rayon Vert chalice.

Pours a nice, fairly-clear amber color with a nice off-white head. Good retention of the foamy white head. Some lacing on the way down and a good cap and collar throughout.

The nose carries some moderate hopping as well as a nice fruitiness and light earthy character. Great presence in the nose, really serving to complement the hops.

Flavor brings a nice bit of fruity hops along with some earth, light malt, and some Brett through the background. Body is light-to-medium with a good bitterness and a nice bit of Brett and earth to really round things out. Quite dry through the finish.

This is a really fantastic beer and Im beyond excited that its year round. This is finally an off-the-shelf year-round beer that is worthy of sitting beside sixers of Two Hearted in my fridge. Bravo, Green Flash.
Bottle. Murky gold with ridiculous head that just doesnt disappear. Earthy, citrus-y, yeasty, grassy, funky. Some noticeable alcohol.

Bottle. Poured amber with a rocky off-white head. Aroma of yeast, Brett, spice, leather, and dark fruits. The flavor found spice (light pepper), Brett, and yeast. Medium body with a spice and yeast aftertaste.
Like Orval? Say hello to its little friend. Just dont use a tulip, the head is a little out of control and just rockets out of the glass.
Nose is banana, Lemon peel, orange, grassy, citrus hops..Taste is soapy, lemon, grains, bready, clove..Palate is dry with light bitterness
Its that good you guys.  Crisp, clean and refreshing with plenty of taste.  I could drink 4 of these every day.

12 oz bottle. Purchased from 16th Ave. Pours a hazy  orange amber with a  light head. Hops and citrus to the nose with maybe a bit of toffee. Nice light malt with oranges and lemons to taste. Fruity. Nice overall balance though leaning towards the hops. A good beer.
12 ounce bottle pour.  Orangish color with a white head that fades.  Nice fresh Brett taste.  Tastes like a homeless mans Orval.

The beer pours a golden-orange color with a white head. The aroma is very nice. I get a ton of brett, as well as some nice leather notes. Hidden in the background are some spice and orange citrus notes. 

The flavor is more of the same. What stands out the most is the brett and orange notes, but there is also quite a bit of leather and white pepper mixed in. The beer is very dry. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very, very nice.

Well, I love Green Flash brews, maybe this was just a poor evaluation after the Hess IPA, but to me Rayon Vert translated into green plastic and I could not shake that association.  I am thinking this is more likely a classic Belgian pale with a little overexuberance on the hops rather than the more trendy IPA with a Belgian yeast and so may rating may reflect different expectations.

12oz into sniffer... ridiculous head. seriously 3-4 fingers. Smell is hard to place. I think Im getting banana and maybe some melon or something like that. Very light and sweet smelling. Tastes sweet and funky, no bitterness that I can detect. I think its delicious.
Pours a cloudy gold with a huge head. Slight banana aroma, and sour flavor. Maybe I should wait until the head is gone tomorrow.

Pours a a dark hazy golden with a full foamy head that lasts a long time.  Aroma is floral and grassy.  Contains some citrus fruit elements; orange, pineapple, along with apple.  Taste is quite hoppy, although it is not overpoweringly so.  It is spicy, and tart, while the citrus from the aromas is most present in the flavor.  Smooth all around.

Holy Schmoly this is going to be a great summer. This beer is just right for a hot day so refreshing.
Aroma is pinapple, pear, candy, floral, lavender, hay and grass with some sweet earthiness
Appearance is the only thing really lacking. HUGE white head that turns to merengue and never leaves. Cloudy yellow with nonstop champagne like bubbles. Honestly a head this big is kind of annoying.
Taste. Is aroma with sweetness on the tongue and a super refreshing cleanliness to the palate that just leaves you wanting another sip.
Overall Im sorry its already gone form my glass and Im looking forward to my next.

2 Apr 2012, bottle, pinkish orange, slightly hazy, steady bubbles, foamy head fades fast. wild nose, so much happening. Brett yeast is first and strongest with the faintest of belgian strong ale alcohol in the background. med/thin body and a bit fizzy. has a certain earthy, cobweb taste, straw, some twinges of sour, and a dried grassy hop flavor. it wouldnt have been my flagship beer but it has some nice elements.

(12oz bottle).  Pours hazy orange-golden with off-white head.  Aroma is belgian yeast, citrus, and a little earthiness.  Taste is sweet with some more earthiness and some mild bitterness.  Medium bodied and oily with a drier finish.  Pretty decent, considering I dont care much for the style.

Bottle at the Flying Saucer, Nashville. Cloudy orange, big dense white head. Smells awesome - bretty funk, Citrus hops, some bubblegum and banana. Like a hoppier Orval, I suppose. Lots of funky notes, plus some fruit. Piney, sticky hops in the finish. I really dug this stuff...

Drank this pretty damn quick, probably one of the better belgian pale ale I have had for a long while, appearance was good, aroma fragrant and taste was grassy lemon brett and light spice. Very drinkable for me.

Bottle from Total Wine, Sacramento. Pours cloudy golden wth a massive beige head and a banana aroma. There is a fresh hop and caramel malt flavor with a huge yeast presence and a dry bitter finish. Quite complex for a Belgian style ale.

Pours a light amber color with a huge white head.  A really nice Brett character.  Heavy on the fruit (especially apple), a bit of pear, lots of straw and grass, and a mild spice.  Some bread and cracker and a light citric quality on the finish.  The flavor is slightly tart and citrusy with lemon and lime notes.  Light tropical fruit character as well as some pear and apple.  Good bread and a mild spice note to it as well.  Really nice.

Pours an orange copper color with a big fluffy lively head that puffed out of the glass.... Definitely some brettanomyces in there, great barnyard aromas with a underlying sour citrus notes.  The flavor explodes just like the aroma with a great rustic backbone rounded out with citrusy hop bitterness and a quality finish.

12oz bottle from Binnys Arlington Heights. Pours hazy golden orange with lively white head. Aromas of citrus, yeast, brett, grassy hops, toasted grains, and some barnyard. Flavors of grassy hops, lemon, brett, yeast, and some peppery spices. Finishes dry. Really nice.
Has a wildly fragrant aroma that really comes through. Pours golden with a thick head. Taste is mild all around, not being overpowering in any respect.

The word Belgian is misleading here.  IPA, or even pale ale would be more appropriate.  The malt is there early, followed by an unusual semi-sweet hop flavor bringing up the rear.  Reasonable, not complex, a little heavy.

12oz Bottle, purchased at Wakefield Liquor - Wakefield, RI. Slightly styrofoamy aroma, with a bit of hop pungency. Spicy and Orval-like. Well carbonated and explosive, as a good Belgian Ale should be. This really reminds me of super-fresh Orval, with more hops. I guess thats what its going for. A little less malt complexity. This is nicely drinkable, but theres not a lot hitting home in the end flavorwise and the palate is really light. Thats fine, if Im paying $1.69, but for the $3.39 I had to shell out for 12oz, Id like a little more action, please.

Bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a hazy dark golden color with a large fluffy white head.  The aroma has grass, herbs, barnyard, toasted malts and Brett character with splashes of fruit and yeast.  The flavor has more of the barnyard funk, grass, toasted malts with Brett influences.  There is a hint of sweet Belgian yeast and sugar working its way in.  Interesting and would like to revisit a bottle in a while to see how it changes.

bottle-Pours darker orange lightly hazy with a fluffy white head that lasted a very long time with sudsy-ness along the sides of the glass.  nose is lite spice, barnyard (funk, mold) lite phenols, lite plastic note, and lite straw.  flavors exhibit alot of the funk yeast qualities along with toasted malt grains, lite spice, lots of bitter hops (for this style) and lingering funk on the finish.  This is alot better than theTreasure Chest beer and one of this breweries best!  body is soft, full yet crisp with the perfect amount of carbonation.  very well done GF

355ml bottle. Lots of loosely packed foam above a copper orange base. Musky perfume aromas, blooming flowers in the spring garden come to mind. The flavour is a bit perfumery as well but it is not too bad. Sits in the mouth well, has a good strong body and 
lingers on the palate.
Man this stuff rocks, a rough Orval with hops... and affordable and fresh.
Wow. Pours cloudy orangey copper. Smell s sweet grass, hay, yeast. Citrus, peppercorn,with piney grassy hops. Incredibl sesionable Belgian.

Bottle. Appearance: very clear golden orange color, white head dissipating quickly. Aroma: first pour whiff almost skunky to me, but I think thats the new style for me that I just dont know (think its a kind of barnyard Brett smell); very earthy almost dirt yeast presence that works well with very sweet honeysuckle and orange and tart lemon citrus scent.  Taste:  strong meyer lemon citrus up front, some caramel malt coming through in the middle, finishing with a kind of lemony tartness and dried leaves taste that lingers a bit; very interesting/different yet delicious.  Mouthfeel: relatively thin, medium "scrubbing" carbonation, very dry finish. Overall: this is my first Brett beer and Im pleasantly surprised.  Didnt know what was going on at first whiff so I looked it up and it made sense.  Dont really love that aroma, but I really like the complexity of taste.

Bottle at Flying Saucer. Pours a cloudy amber with a medium frothy off white head leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is pepper and yeast. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet malt and light dry finish. A good belgian from Green Flash.

12 oz bottle.  Misty orange brown with white frosting.  Nose is grass, honey, horse stall and bubblegum.  Medium light, oily and fizzy with sharp carb.  Taste is yeast, lime peel, tart green apple and toffee finishing with quinine and grass.

Bottle. Pours hazy copper big off-white head. Interesting aroma of citrus and spice and earthy yeast. Taste is not overly sweet or bitter. Good amount of malt, medium body, soft carbonation, mild bitter finish with spice. Overall this was unique and pretty good for a style thats not my favorite.
Bottle at Girl and the Goat. Cloudy amber - offwhite head. Nice hoppy. Cactus. Nice fruity. Lovely Bretty.Citrus. Bamboo. Nutty. Lovely fresh hoppy. Light belgian yeasty.

I dont know, I guess its a 12oz bottle, but it could also be 33cl.  Pours a mostly clear, bright gold with a frothy, clumpy white head.  Nose is a really nice mix of Belgian yeasty esters and nice lemony hops, earthy, cloves, leafy veg, candy sugar, a little bit of birch.  Flavor is sweet, spicy, candy sugar, lemons, oranges, mint, birch, earthy, grass, hay.  Medium bodied finish.  I know this is a take on Orval, but it needed a touch more Brett to be in the same league.  As is though, its very nice.  Complex but drinkable.  Could be sessionable if it wasnt 7% abv.
Cloudy amber,lasting fluffy white head.Tart spicy yeast nose. More of same in palate.Good body, great lacing. Effervescent
Bottle pours a gold/amber with a massive frothy off white head. Scent is yeast, fruit and spice. Taste is tart, yeast and spice with an earthy finish.

pours a cloudy pale gold, big pillowy head.  very funky in flavor and aroma, very dry and fruity, moderately bitter, very dry finish, very satisfying.  this is the real deal, definitely not a half-assed belgian attempt., and something about it comes together in a way that makes me wanna get this stuff all the time.

On tap at the Brass Tap, poured a dark golden color with aromas of pepper, spice, floral hops, and yeast esters.  Flavors are the same, had a slight sweet taste that mixed with the esters and peppery yeast.

Bottle from King&Godfree. Great aromatic hops, with well balanced flavour. Aromas of citrus, pine, honey, bread, with hints of caramel. Taste is sweet, with light bitter and sour notes, long length. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Amber, with a frothy head.

Green Flash is probably one of the most underrated breweries on the west coast... Citrusy aroma, light orange in color... Flavor is citrus, belgian yeast, spices, and slightly tart finish... Delicious beer!

Bottle.  Pours hazy dark straw golden with 3-finger off-white head.  Nose is a great mix of floral hops, black peppery spice, funky yeasty malt.  Tastes floral, not dry but somewhat sweet, with funky yeast esters, hops, peppery and coriandery spice, and a complex finish.  This one is delicious, and one of the best of its style ever made.

Hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of spices, honey, brett, vanilla, citrus, and toffee.  Taste of grass, light citrus, vanilla, leather, some spices, and a bretty finish.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy gold with a nice long lasting white head.  Unusual aroma of florals, fruit, hops, and barnyard.  Taste is hops, malt, pine, citrus, and yeast.  A bit different (hard to describe) but very enjoyable.

Pours a slightly hazy deep golden color with a huge fluffy white head that persists forever. 
Smells of pepper and spice mostly. Light hints of sweet honey like malt countered with grapefruit and zest. Taste is spicy with pepper, lightly sweet with honey like malt, lemony and citrusy with hops. Medium body with a spirited level of carbonation and a fizzy syrupy chalky mouthfeel. Decent Belgian pale that Im glad I got to try, but probably not something I would seek out again.

12-oz. Pours a cloudy bright medium amber with a dense and creamy white head that sticks around and around. Dense rings of sedimentary lace. Big bubble gum watermelon nose with plenty of herbal hop lingering around...interesting combination. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Sweet bubble gum and watermelon mid palate with a sweet finish.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2014 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Superb, bright orange pour with a small, firm white head with lovely spider legs all the way down the glass. Nose is pretty much taken over by the brett with heavy tropical fruits. Quite grassy behind it but the brett is very in your face.
